Articles.Content:
Hi to all! I've just made a simple chart with GeoGebra, I think's it's nice so I decided to post it here.

It shows the delta-v needed to change your orbital inclination in function of the inclination change:

It's not tested yet, so I'm not 100% sure if the readings given are ok!! (will try tomorrow. EDIT: just tested, it works fine)

Notes: It refers to circular orbits around Kerbin. Height indicated is the same as in-game (it's not orbital radius). Initial and final orbits are both circular and with the same semi-major axis.

Better resolution: (maybe too big!)

http://imgur.com/hgPl4kt

If you want to get a look to the source(It's a geogebra file, so you'll need it to visualize):

https://www.dropbox.com/s/ic1utlu3ly1qvlg/Deltav-inclination%20Chart.zip

Maybe that's not very useful, but it's nice.

EDIT: comment if you liked!

Edited May 17, 2014 by PlonioFludrasco
Damn those plane changes are expensive. 500 m/s to do a little over 10 degree plane change from 100km. Unbelievable.
Well, you're hurtling along at 2300 m/s there, so trying to divert that to the side is not easy
Ok, I've had a couple of tests about that chart and seems it works fine.

Damn those plane changes are expensive. 500 m/s to do a little over 10 degree plane change from 100km. Unbelievable.

Plane changes suck. Period.

Plane changes suck. Period.

Agree, but if you want to do it, here's how much delta-v you'll need.
